description: Demolition of the existing Peterhead Court residential building, community centre and maintenance office and the construction of four 3-storey high houses (4 x 4B Rented tenure) and four 4-6 storey high apartment buildings comprising 64 flats (2 x 1B and 8 x 2B Market Sale tenure; 4 x 1B, 13 x 2B and 19 x 3B Rented tenure; 1 x 1B and 17 x 2B Intermediate tenure); a new community centre and nursery comprising 388m2 floorspace (D1 Use Class); associated bicycle, refuse + recycling storage facilities; associated hard and soft landscaping; and alterations to Osborne Road to incorporate new footways and revised / new car parking arrangements (Regulation 3 Application by the London Borough of Ealing).
decision_conditions: The development permitted shall be begun before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission.  Reason: In order to comply with the provisions of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended). | The development hereby permitted shall be carried out in accordance with the following approved plans: (1433_PL_) 001 D, 002 D, 003 C, 004 B, 010 F, 100 L, 101 J, 102 H, 103 D, 200 F, 201 A, 202 G, 250 A, 300 C, 301 C, 302 B; (6834/) 1, 1B, 2, 3; Daylight and Sunlight and Overshadowing Report ref: 27495 (dated 09/06/2015) and Addendum (dated 19/06/2015), prepared Baily Garner LLP; Design and Access Statement (dated 19/06/2015), prepared by PCKO; Drainage Strategy Statement ref: 11433 (dated June 2015), prepared by Tully D'Ath Consultants; Energy Strategy Report ref: 27495 (Issue 01), (dated 22/05/2015), prepared by Baily Garner; Transport Statement and Travel Plan ref: TC/616782/LAB (dated June 2015), prepared by MLM consulting Engineers Ltd; Ventilation strategy Report ref: 27586 (dated 09/06/2015), prepared by Baily Garner; Desk Study Report ref: DS2590 (dated 10/06/2015), prepared by Southern Testing Laboratories Limited; Peterhead Court Schedule of Accommodation Rev A (dated 29/07/2015), prepared by PCKO.      Reason: For the avoidance of doubt and in the interests of proper planning. | The development hereby approved shall be provided in accordance with the details contained in the Peterhead Court Schedule of Accommodation Rev A (dated 29/07/2015), prepared by PCKO and the approved Design and Access Statement (dated 19/06/2015), prepared by PCKO and the approved Proposed Tenure Plans ref: (1433_PL_) 300 B, 301 B, 302 B. Of the approved 68 units, 40 units (4 x 1-bedroom flats, 13 x 2-bedroom flats, 19 x 3-bedroom flats and 4 x 4-bedroom houses) shall be provided in Affordable Rent tenure; 18 units (1 x 1-bedroom flats and 17 x 2-bedroom flats) shall be provided in Intermediate tenure.  Reason: To ensure that the affordable housing is provided in accordance with the approved plans and documents, in accordance with policies 3.11, 3.12, 3.13 and 3.14 of the London Plan (2015); policy 1.2(a) of Ealing's adopted Development (or Core) Strategy 2026 (2012); and policy 3A of Ealing's adopted Development Management DPD (2013). | The existing Golf Links Estate Community Centre shall be available for use and not decommissioned until the replacement 388m community centre and crFche are re-provided and ready for use.  Reason: To ensure the continuity of use of the community centre, in accordance with policy 3.1 of the London Plan (2015); and policies 1.1(e) and 1.2(d) of Ealing's Development (or Core) Strategy 2026 (2012) . | Development shall not commence on the approved development until a construction management plan is submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The submission shall include the following information:  a) A demolition and construction phasing plan for the approved development, based on approved drawing 1433_PL_004 B; b) Details of the number of on-site construction workers and of the transport options for them; c) anticipated route, anticipated number, frequency and size of construction vehicles entering/exiting the site per day; d) delivery times and booking system; e) route and location of site access for construction traffic and associated signage based on the construction vehicle access and egress routes; f) management of consolidated or re-timed trips; g) an AQDMP that includes an Air Quality (Dust) Risk Assessment and details of noise/vibration mitigation measures and monitoring arrangements for noise, vibration and dust by suitably qualified noise and air quality specialists.  Noise/vibration and dust mitigation measures must accord with the Mayor's SPG 'The control of dust and emissions from construction and demolition ' (2014); BS 5228 Parts 1 & 2; the Institute of Air Quality Management 'Guidance on the assessment of dust from demolition and construction'; h) details of site security and the erection and maintenance of security hoarding including decorative displays and facilities for public viewing, where appropriate; i) secure, off-street loading and drop-off facilities; j) vehicle manoeuvring and turning, including swept path diagrams to demonstrate how construction vehicles will access the site and be able to turn into and emerge from the site in forward gear and including details of any temporary vehicle access points; k) details of the location for storage of building materials and construction debris and contractors offices; l) procedures for on-site contractors to deal with complaints from members of the public; m) measures to consult cyclists, disabled people and the local schools with regard  to delivery times and necessary diversions; n) details of all pedestrian and cyclist diversions; o) a commitment to be part of Considerate Constructors Scheme; and p) confirmation of use of TfL's Freight Operator Recognition Scheme (FORS) or similar.  Prior to the commencement of any site work, all sensitive properties within or surrounding the site shall be notified in writing of the nature and duration of the works to be undertaken, and the name and address of a responsible person to whom enquiries / complaints should be directed. These details shall also be displayed at regular intervals around the site compound. The development shall be carried out strictly in accordance with the details so approved.  Reason:  The details of a site construction management plan is required before the commencement of the development in order to ensure that appropriate mitigation measures are in place to protect the amenity of local residents that live in close proximity to the demolition and construction site and to ensure adequate highway and site safety, in accordance with policies 5.3, 5.18, 6.3, 7.14, 7.15 and 7.19 of the London Plan (2015); policies 1.1(e), (f) and (j) of Ealing's Development (or Core) Strategy 2026 (2012); policy 7A of Ealing's Development Management DPD (2013); (Interim) SPG 10: Noise and Vibration; the National Planning Policy Framework (2012); the Greater London Authority SPG 'The Control of Dust and Emissions from Construction and Demolition' (2014), BS 5228-1:2009 - Code of practice for noise & vibration control on construction & open sites-Part 1: Noise. | Development shall not commence (excluding demolition, site clearance and preparation works) until the following details for each phase of development are submitted to the Local Planning Authority for written approval:  a) An intrusive contaminated land investigation and risk assessment of the site, carried out in accordance with BS1075:2011+A1:2013 and CR11 guidance, to assess the nature and extent of any contamination on the site. This assessment must be undertaken by a competent person and shall assess any contamination on the site.    b) A contamination remediation scheme to bring the relevant part of the site to a condition suitable for the intended end use. The scope of the remediation scheme shall include details of all works to be undertaken, proposed remediation objectives and remediation criteria, a timetable of works and site management procedures.  The remediation scheme must ensure that the site will not qualify as contaminated land under Part 2A of the Environmental Protection Act 1990 in relation to the intended use of the land after remediation.  Within six-months of the completion of measures identified in the approved contamination remediation scheme for each phase of development, a verification report (in accordance with the Environment Agency guidance 'Verification of Remediation of Land Contamination', Report: SC030114/R1') that demonstrates the effectiveness of the remediation carried out shall be submitted to the Local Planning Authority for written approval.   Reason: Further investigations of the presence of soil contamination within the application site and details of the methods for remediation are required before the commencement of building works in order to ensure that human health and the environment are protected, in accordance with the recommendations of the approved Desk Study Report ref: DS2590 (dated 10/06/2015), prepared by Southern Testing Laboratories Limited, and to ensure the development activities do not activate or spread contamination in accordance with policies LV5.21 and 7A of Ealing's Development Management DPD (2013), policy 5.21 of the London Plan (2015), and the Mayor's Sustainable Design and Construction SPG. | Development shall not commence (excluding demolition, site clearance and preparation works) until a piling risk assessment and method statement have been submitted to the Local Planning Authority for written approval. The piling risk assessment should demonstrate that the chosen method of piling would not increase the risk of near-surface pollutants migrating into deeper geological formations and aquifers. The Piling Method Statement should include details of the type of piling to be undertaken and the methodology by which such piling would be carried out, including measures to prevent and minimise the potential for damage to subsurface water or sewage infrastructure. The development shall thereafter be carried out in accordance with the approved details.  Reason: Details of piling are required before the sub-structure works commence because Thames Water would require that any proposed piling methods do not pose a pollution risk to controlled waters, water or sewage infrastructure in accordance with policy 5.14 of the London Plan (2015) and policy 1.1(j) of Ealing's Development (or Core) Strategy (2012). | Within six months of the commencement of development, the adoption details for the surface water drainage scheme, described in the approved Drainage Strategy Statement ref: 11433 (dated June 2015) prepared by Tully D'Ath Consultants and the clarification email regarding the drainage strategy dated 04/08/2015, and details of the on-going maintenance arrangements shall be submitted to the Local Planning Authority for written approval.  The detailed surface water drainage scheme described in the approved Drainage Strategy Statement ref: 11433 (dated June 2015), prepared by Tully D'Ath Consultants and the clarification email regarding the drainage strategy, dated 04/08/2015, shall be implemented prior to the first occupation of the completed development and the proposed run-off rates, volumes and SuDs features shall be managed and maintained in accordance with the approved strategy in perpetuity.  Reason: In the interests of providing adequate drainage to reduce the risk of flooding to the proposed development and locality, and to enhance water quality and biodiversity, in accordance with the objectives of Section 11 of the NPPF; policies 5.3, 5.12, 5.13 and 5.14 of the London Plan (2015); policy 1.2(m) of Ealing's Development (or Core) Strategy 2026 (2012); and policy LV5.12 of Ealing's Development Management DPD (2013). | Within six months of the commencement of development, further details of the landscaping proposals and boundary treatments illustrated on approved drawing 1422_PL_010 F and as detailed in the approved Design and Access Statement (prepared by PCKO), shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The details shall include the following matters (in relation to the relevant phase of development):  a) Full details of the design of the children play areas, including safety surfacing and equipment (where relevant); b) Soft landscaping: including grass and turf areas, hedges, shrub and herbaceous areas, allotments and tree strategy including species type and size at planting. Tree species should include a palette of different species of trees in order to avoid streets and long sections of landscaping that are planted in monocultures; c) Hard landscaping: including ground surfaces, kerbs, edges, ridge and flexible paving, seating or other public realm furniture, steps, and any synthetic surfaces and a drawing illustrating the Local Highways Authority adoption boundary; d) Enclosures and boundary treatments, including types, dimensions and finishes of walls, fences, screen walls, barriers, bollards, rails, retaining walls and hedges (as relevant); e) A statement detailing how the landscaping proposals contribute to the mitigation measures for nesting birds, the enablement of species to migrate such as hedgehogs and other small mammals through gaps in fencing and ecological enhancements, including the number and location of swift boxes, sparrow terrace, bat bricks, bee boxes and other measures to enhance ecology (as relevant);  f) Work phasing plan.  All soft landscaping shall be carried out in the earliest planting season (1st October to 31st March inclusive). The quality of all approved landscape works shall be in accordance with British Standard 4428:1989 'Code of Practice for General Landscape Operations' or any subsequent revision.  All trees included within the approved scheme shall be healthy, well-formed specimens with single leading shoots and shall be of a minimum quality compatible with British Standard 3936:1992 (Part 1) 'Specifications For Trees & Shrubs' and British Standard 4043 (where applicable) or any subsequent revisions and BS: 8545:2014 Trees: from nursery to independence in the landscape.  Any trees that within a period of 5 years from the completion of all tree planting, that die, are removed, uprooted, are significantly damaged, become diseased or malformed shall be replaced during the nearest planting season (1st October to 31st March inclusive) with others of the same size, species and quality as approved. The development shall thereafter be carried out in accordance with the approved plans and work phasing plan.   Boundary treatments shall be fully provided before the first occupation of the part of development which it forms part. The approved details shall be retained thereafter.   Reason: To ensure that the development is landscaped in the interests of the positive visual character and appearance of the area; to ensure that the necessary boundary treatments are incorporated into the development in the interests of meeting the Secured by Design principles; in order to ensure that the site landscaping is provided in accordance with an agreed timeframe; and in order to provide a good level of privacy for future users / occupants, in accordance with policies LV2.18, LV7.3, LV7.4, 7B and 7D of Ealing's Development Management DPD (2013); 2.18, 7.4, 7.13, 7.19 and 7.21 of the London Plan (2015); 1.1(h) and (i), 2.10, 5.3, 5.4 and 6.3 of Ealing's Development (or Core) Strategy 2026 (2012), and interim SPG 9 'Trees and Development Guidelines'. | Within six months of the commencement of the development, the details of the layout of the 15 parking spaces within Osborne Road (the adopted highway) and the 15 parking spaces outside of the adopted highway shall be submitted to the Local Planning Authority for written approval. The details of the layout of parking shall include the following information:  a) Evidence of a Road Safety Audit and designer's response to the Road Safety Audit;  b) Location and layout of six parking spaces that are suitably sized for wheelchair users;  c) Provision for five (5) street tree pits in the approximate location of the gaps between parking spaces 1 and 2; 3 and 4; 5 and 6; 19 and 20; and 22 and 23, as illustrated on approved drawing 1433_PL_010 F, or another location subject to agreement; d) Details of 3 active charging points for electric vehicles, with an additional 3 passive charging points for electric vehicles that are suitable for later adaptation if required.  The tree pits shall be suitable for a small tree (5m-10m high) to grow, which requires 10m of non-compacted soil space, or a medium tree (15m), which requires 12-15m of non-compacted soil space.  Reason: In the interests of providing safe and accesibile parking facilities; in order to provide a satisfactory growing environment for the new street trees to be provided by the Council's Parks Service, in the interests of the visual amenities and the biodiversity value of the area and the setting and character of the proposed development; and in the interest of improving air quality; in accordance with policies: 6.13, 7.14, 7.19 and 7.21 of the London Plan (2015); 1.1(i) of Ealing's Development (or Core) Strategy 2026 (2012); and policy LV5.10 of Ealing's Development Management DPD (2013) and interim SPG 9: Trees and Development Guidelines. | Sound insulation and noise control measures for the approved residential dwellings shall be installed to achieve the internal noise targets described at Section 4(B) 'Criteria for adequate protection for new buildings' of Ealing's interim SPG 10:  Bedrooms (23:00-0700 hrs) 30 dB LAeq, and 45 dB Lmax (fast) Living rooms (0700-2300 hrs) 35dB LAeq Kitchens, bathrooms, WC and utility rooms (0700-2300 hrs) 45 dB LAeq  The sound insulation and noise control measures shall be installed prior to the first use and / or first occupation of the relevant part of the development and maintained thereafter.  Reason: To protect the amenity of the residential occupiers of the new development, in accordance with policies 3.2, 3.18 and 7.15 of the London Plan (2015); policy 1.1(j) of Ealing's Development (or Core) Strategy (2012); policy 7A of Ealing's Development Management DPD (2013); the Mayor's Sustainable Design and Construction SPG; and interim SPG 10: Noise and Vibration. | Sound limiting insulation shall be installed between the approved crFche, community centre and the adjoining dwellings located above these non-residential uses prior to the first occupation of the relevant part of the development, to achieve an acoustic standard not exceeding NR 25 Leq, 5mins (octaves) or NR 20 Leq, 5mins, (one-third octaves) inside a bedroom, and NR 30 Leq, 5mins (octaves) or NR 25 Leq, 5mins (one-third octaves) inside a habitable room when noise is generated from the community uses and the sound limiting insulation shall be retained thereafter.   Reason: To ensure a satisfactory standard of residential amenity is provided for future occupiers of the residential units located above the approved community floorspace and creche, in accordance with policies 3.2 and 7.15 of the London Plan (2015); policy 1.1(j) of Ealing's Development (or Core) Strategy 2026 (2012); policy 7A of Ealing's Development Management DPD (2013), and interim SPG 10: Noise and Vibration. | The rating noise level emitted from any proposed plant and machinery within the development, as assessed under BS4142: 2014, shall not exceed the existing background noise level as measured at nearest ground floor sensitive facade and 1m from upper floor noise sensitive facades, during the relevant periods of operation.  Reason: To ensure a satisfactory standard of amenity is provided for occupiers / users of the residential, education and community buildings, in accordance with policies 3.2 and 7.15 of the London Plan (2015); policy 1.1(j) of Ealing's Development (or Core) Strategy 2026 (2012); policy 7A of Ealing's Development Management DPD (2013); interim SPG 10: Noise and Vibration; and the Mayor's Sustainable Design and Construction SPG. | The approved community uses (community centre and creche) located at ground floor level of the approved residential apartment building shall only operate during the hours of 0700 - 2300 on weekdays and Saturday, and 0700 - 2200 on Sunday and Public Holidays.  Reason: To ensure a satisfactory standard of residential amenity is provided for future occupiers of the apartments located above the community uses and to prevent noise and disturbance caused by patrons leaving the community facilities, in accordance with policies 7.15 of the London Plan (2015); 1.1(j) of Ealing's adopted Development (or Core) Strategy 2026 (2012); and policy 7A of Ealing's Development Management DPD (2013). | Prior to the first occupation of the approved community centre, the details of the extract and supply ventilation system and details of the on-going maintenance arrangements for the system to control cooking odours from the kitchen shall be submitted to the Local Planning Authority for written approval. The kitchen shall be fitted-out with the extract and supply ventilation system before its first use and the system shall thereafter be maintained in accordance with approved details.  Reason: To ensure a satisfactory standard of residential amenity is provided for future occupiers of the apartments located above the community uses and to assist to prevent cooking odours caused by the preparation of cooked meals, in accordance with policies 7.15 of the London Plan (2015); 1.1(j) of Ealing's adopted Development (or Core) Strategy 2026 (2012); and policy 7A of Ealing's Development Management DPD (2013). | Ultra-Low NOx boilers with maximum NOx Emissions of <40 mgNOx/kWh shall be installed within each of the approved dwellings.  Reason: To minimise the impact of building emissions on local air quality in the interests of health, in accordance with policies 3.2 and 7.14 of the London Plan 2015; the Mayor's Sustainable Design and Construction SPG; policies 1.1(e) and (j) of Ealing's Development (or Core) Strategy 2012, and policy 7A of Ealing's Development Management DPD (2013). | The approved development shall incorporate measures to achieve an overall reduction in regulated CO2 emissions of at least 37.23% beyond Building Regulations Part L 2013 through the following carbon emission savings, as detailed in the approved Energy Strategy Report ref: 27495 (Issue 01), (dated 22/05/2015), prepared by Baily Garner:   a) energy saving measures to achieve at least 2.13% savings in regulated carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions beyond the complaint Building Regulations Part L 2013 base case; b) installation of solar PV technology to achieve at least 87kWp (c.580m2) (and equal to 38 tonnes CO2 / annum or 35.86% over Be Clean Stage) in regulated carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions beyond the 'Be Clean' stage.  Within twelve-months of the first occupation of each Phase of development, the applicant shall submit the Energy Performance Certificates [EPC's] and accompany advisory reports for the development and modelling output reports from the "as built stage" (to confirm compliance in terms of savings achieved through energy efficiency measures) to the Local Planning Authority for written approval.  Reason: To secure the measures set out within the approved Energy Statement and to ensure that the energy efficiency measures to be incorporated into the approved development contribute to reducing the use of fossil fuel or other primary energy generation capacity, and to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases, and to minimise the impact of building emissions on local air quality in the interests of health, in accordance with policies 3.2, 5.3, 5.5, 5.6 and 7.14 of the London Plan (2015), policies 1.1(e), 1.1(j), 1.1(k) and 1.2(f) of Ealing's adopted Development (or Core) Strategy 2026 (2012), policies LV5.2 and 7A of Ealing's Development Management DPD (2013), and the Mayor's Sustainable Design and Construction SPG. | The scheme of photovoltaic panels which shall provide for no less than 87kWp (c.580 m2 roof area) as indicatively shown on the approved drawing 1433_PL_103 D and in accordance with the approved Energy Strategy Report ref: 27495 (Issue 01), (dated 22/05/2015), prepared by Baily Garner, shall be eligible under relevant standards of the Microgeneration Certification Scheme and installed and operational prior to the first occupation of the part of the development on which the photovoltaic panels are located.    Reason:  In the interest of sustainable development and combating climate change in accordance with policies 5.1, 5.2, 5.3 and 5.7 of the London Plan 2015; policies 1.1(k) and 1.2(f) of Ealing's Development (or Core) Strategy 2012; and policy LV 5.2 of Ealing's Development Management DPD (2013). | The biodiversity roofs shall be laid out in accordance with the approved drawing 1433_PL_103 D and incorporate the following:  a) Be biodiversity based with extensive substrate base (depth 80-150mm);  b) Have sufficient depth of soil or growing medium for the relevant planting, including the re-use of any demolition material where feasible; c) Be planted / seeded with a mix of species within the first planting season following the practical completion of the building works. The seed mix shall be focused on wildflower planting and shall contain no more than 25% sedum; d) Have relevant efficient and effective drainage and irrigation to sustain the vegetation.  The biodiversity roofs shall not be used as an amenity or sitting out area and shall only be accessed in the case of essential maintenance or repair. The biodiversity roofs shall be retained thereafter.  Reason:  To ensure the development provides the maximum possible provision towards the creation of habitats and valuable areas for biodiversity in accordance with policies 5.3, 5.10, 5.11, 5.12 and 7.19 of the London Plan (2015); policies 1.1(j), (k) and 1.2(m) of Ealing's Development (or Core) Strategy (2012); and policies LV5.10 and LV5.11 of Ealing's Development Management DPD (2013). | The development shall be designed to achieve a water use target for the residential development of no more than 110 litres per person per day, and community uses (community centre and creche) shall also incorporate water saving measures and equipment.  Reason: To ensure the sustainable use of water, in accordance with policy 5.15 of the London Plan (2015). | Details and samples of all facing materials shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority prior to any work commencing on the superstructure of the relevant Phase of development. The samples and details shall include:  a) brickwork (including brick panels and mortar courses); b) cladding materials; c) all window treatments (including details of window certification for Secured by Design); d) building entrance details and material samples (including details of door certification for Secured by Design); e) balcony structures and balustrading treatment (including sections);  f) privacy screen treatment;  g) sub-station, refuse and bicycle store entrance doors and ventilation louvres (including details of door certification for Secured by Design);  h) details of the design of the residential letterboxes (including confirmation that the letterboxes meet PAS 24:2012);  i) any other materials to be used.  The development shall be carried out strictly in accordance with the details so approved and retained thereafter.  Reason: To ensure that the materials are of a high-quality specification and make a positive contribution to the townscape, in accordance with policy 7B of Ealing's Development Management DPD (2013), policy 1.1(h) of Ealing's Development (or Core) Strategy 2026 (2012), and policies 7.1 and 7.6 of the London Plan (2015). | The bicycle storage facilities comprising 22 spaces in Core A, 34 spaces in Core B, 40 spaces in Core D, and 34 spaces in Core E, as well as the 4 visitor bicycle parking spaces, as illustrated on approved drawing 1433_PL_100 L shall be ready for use prior to the first occupation of any dwelling in the relevant core of the apartment building(s) and / or terraced houses (as relevant), or the first use of the community uses to which the cycle parking storage serves and shall be retained thereafter.   Reason: To ensure adequate cycle parking is provided within the development in pursuance of the objectives of sustainability and encouraging the use of modes of transport other than private motor vehicles in accordance with policy 6.9 of the London Plan (2015), policies 1.1(k) and (g) of Ealing's Development (or Core) Strategy 2026 (2012), and Ealing's Sustainable Transport for New Development SPG. | The dedicated refuse and recycling enclosures for the residential and community uses shown on the approved drawing 1433_PL_100 L shall be provided prior to the first occupation of any dwelling in the relevant core of the apartment building(s) and / or terraced houses (as relevant), or the first use of the community uses (as relevant) to which the store serves and shall be retained thereafter.  		 Reason:  To secure the necessary recycling and waste enclosures to support the development and to ensure that responsible waste management practices are adhered to in the interests of the visual amenity of the area and in accordance with policy 5.17 of the London Plan (2015); policy 1.1(e) of Ealing's Development (or Core) Strategy 2026 (2012); policies 7A, LV7.4 and 7B of Ealing's Development Management DPD (2013); and interim SPG 4: Refuse and Recyling Facilities. | The approved residential development shall be designed and constructed to meet the Lifetime Homes Standards, or other such relevant technical requirements in use at the time of the construction of the development.                               Reason:  To ensure that the development is adaptable, flexible, convenient and appropriate to the changing needs of the future occupiers, in accordance with policies 3.5, 3.8 and 3.9 of the London Plan (2015); and policy 1.1(h) of Ealing's Development (or Core) Strategy 2026 (2012). | The adaptable wheelchair user dwellings comprising 1 x one-bedroom, 4 x two-bedroom, and 2 x three-bedroom units shall be designed and constructed to meet Approved Document M (Volume 1: Dwellings), Part M4(3) (Wheelchair user dwellings) of Building Regulations 2015, or other such relevant technical standards in use at the time of the construction of the development.  Reason: To ensure the provision of wheelchair housing in a timely fashion that would address the current unmet housing need; produce a sustainable mix of accommodation; and provide an appropriate choice and housing opportunity for wheelchair users and their families, in accordance with the objectives of policies: 3.5, 3.8 and 3.9 of the London Plan 2015; and policy 1.1(h) of Ealing's Development (or Core) Strategy 2012. | All passenger lifts serving the residential apartment buildings hereby approved shall be installed and operational prior to the first occupation of the relevant part of the building served by a passenger lift and retained in working order thereafter.   Reason:  To ensure that adequate access is provided to all floors of the development for all occupiers and visitors including those with disabilities, in accordance with policies 3.5, 3.8 and 3.9 of the London Plan (2015); the Mayor's SPG 'Accessible London: Achieving an inclusive environment'; policy 1.1(h) of Ealing's Development (or Core) Strategy 2026 (2012); and policy 7B of Ealing's Development Management DPD (2013). | Notwithstanding the provisions of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) Order 2015 (or any order revoking and re-enacting that Order with or without modification) no development to any dwellinghouse hereby approved under Classes A-H (inclusive) of Part 1, Schedule 2 to the said Order shall be carried out or constructed without express planning permission.   Reason:  To enable the Local Planning Authority to maintain control over extensions and other alterations to dwellinghouses in the interests of the design and character of the properties, the visual amenities of the locality and amenities of occupiers of neighbouring properties and in view of the limited area of the private gardens assocaited with the houses, in accordance with policies 7.1, 7.4 and 7.6 of the London Plan 2015, policies 1.1(h) and 1.2(f) of the Ealing's Development (or Core) Strategy 2012 and policies LV7.4, 7B and 7D of Ealing's Development Management DPD (2013). | Prior to the first occupation of any part of the approved development, a final Travel Plan shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. As part of the Travel Plan measures, the introduction of a car club vehicle within the application site shall be further investigated and evidence of this investigation shall be submitted with the Travel Plan. In the event that a car club operator agrees to implement a car club, each new household within the approved development shall be offered free membership of the car club for a period of three-years from the first occupation of each phase of the development. The measures set out in the approved Travel Plan shall be implemented on the first occupation of the development.   Reason: In the interest of supporting measures that encourage shifts to more sustainable modes of transport, in accordance with policies 6.1 and 6.3 of the London Plan
site_number: Golf Links Community Centre, Golf Links Estate
